pageContent.html:
Chapter 13: Password Policy Commands

Password policies are managed from the Main Control Panel, Settings tab, Security section, Password Policies, and can also be managed from command line using the <RLI_HOME>/bin/vdsconfig utility.

This chapter explains how to add, update, and remove a password policy using the <RLI_HOME>/bin/vdsconfig utility instead of the GUI mentioned above.

print-pwd-policy

This command prints the current settings for a given password policy.

Usage: print-pwd-policy -name [-instance ]

Command Arguments:

  • name

[required] The password policy name. Use the value 'default' to refer to the default password policy.

  • instance

The name of the RadiantOne instance. If not specified, the default instance named vds_server is used.

REST (ADAP) Example In the following example, a request is made to display the settings for the default password policy.

https://:8090/adap/util?action=vdsconfig&commandname=print-pwd- policy&name=default 
https://<rli_server_name>:8090/adap/util?action=vdsconfig&commandname=print-pwd-
policy&name=default

add-pwd-policy

This command adds a new custom password policy.

Usage: add-pwd-policy -basedn -name -type [-instance ] [-precedence ] [-pwdAllowUserChange ] [-pwdDictionaryFilePath ] [-pwdEnableAlgorithmUpgrade ] [-pwdEnableLastLogonTime ] [-pwdEnableNotContainNames ] [-pwdExpireWarning ] [-pwdFailureCountInterval ] [-pwdGraceAuthNLimit ] [-pwdIdleLockoutInterval ] [-pwdInHistory ] [-pwdLockoutDuration ] [-pwdLogonTimeSyncInterval ] [-pwdMaxAge ] [-pwdMaxFailure ] [-pwdMinAge ] [-pwdMinLength ] [-pwdMustChange ] [-pwdQualityMinAlteredChar ] [-pwdQualityMinDigitChar ] [-pwdQualityMinLowercaseChar ] [-pwdQualityMinSpecialChar ] [-pwdQualityMinUppercaseChar ] [-pwdSafeModify ] [-pwdStorageScheme ] [pwdStrRule ]

Command Arguments:

  • basedn

[required] The base DN for the subject of the password policy.

  • name

[required] The password policy name. Use the value 'default' to update the default password policy.

  • type

[required] The type of subject. Accepted values are: group, subtree

  • instance

The name of the RadiantOne instance. If not specified, the default instance named vds_server is used.

  • precedence

The precedence, used to resolve conflicts between password policies. A lower precedence value indicates a higher priority. The highest precedence is 1 and the lowest is 1000. The default value is 1000.

  • pwdAllowUserChange

Indicates whether users can change their own passwords. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is true.

  • pwdDictionaryFilePath

Indicates the path to the dictionary file that RadiantOne should use to verify user passwords don’t contain unallowed strings.

  • pwdEnableAlgorithmUpgrade

If enabled, user accounts that contain a password encryption with a less secure method than the one set for the current password policy are automatically updated to the stronger encryption after a successful bind.

  • pwdEnableLastLogonTime

Indicates if the policy should keep track of the user’s last successful logon time. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is false.

  • pwdEnableNotContainNames

The password must not contain the user's account name or parts of the user's full name.

  • pwdExpireWarning

Used to send a warning, this argument allows a user to set the amount of time before the password expires to send a warning. Default is 0 (no warnings). You can indicate the length of time in any combination of days, hours and/or minutes using “d” for days (e.g. 1d), “h” for hours

(e.g. 4h), and “m” for minutes (e.g. 5m).

  • pwdFailureCountInterval

The number of minutes after which the failure count is reset. The default is 0.

  • pwdGraceAuthNLimit

The number of grace login attempt(s) allowed after the password expires. Default is 0.

  • pwdIdleLockoutInterval

The number of day(s) that a user is allowed to be idle before his account is locked. Default value is 0. Note: the -pwdEnableLastLogonTime option must have been set to true for this parameter to be taken into account.

  • pwdInHistory

The maximum number of used passwords to keep in the 'pwdHistory' attribute. Default is 0.

  • pwdLockoutDuration

The number of minutes that an account is locked out for. 0 indicates permanent lockout. The default is 0.

  • pwdLogonTimeSyncInterval

The frequency at which the time of the last successful authentication is recorded.

  • pwdMaxAge

The amount of time after which the password expires. Default is 0 (password never expires). You can indicate the length of time in any combination of days, hours and/or minutes using “d” for days (e.g. 1d), “h” for hours (e.g. 4h), and “m” for minutes (e.g. 5m). A value of 1d would indicate a maximum password age of 1 day.

  • pwdMaxFailure

The maximum number of login failures to allow, before lockout occurs. The default is 0.

  • pwdMinAge

The amount of time that must elapse between modifications to the password. Default is 0 (meaning no limit is enforced). You can indicate the length of time in any combination of days, hours and/or minutes using “d” for days (e.g. 1d), “h” for hours (e.g. 4h), and “m” for minutes (e.g. 5m).

  • pwdMinLength

The minimum number of characters that must be used in a password. Default is 0.

  • pwdMustChange

Indicates if users must change their passwords when they first bind to the directory after their password has been reset by an administrator. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is false.

[-pwdQualityMinAlteredChar ]

The minimum number of characters that must be changed when a new password is set.

  • pwdQualityMinDigitChar

The minimum number of numerical characters required in passwords. Default is 0.

  • pwdQualityMinLowercaseChar

The minimum number of lower-case characters (a-z) required in passwords. Default is 0.

  • pwdQualityMinSpecialChar

The minimum number of special characters (non-alphanumeric 7 - bit ASCII) required in passwords. Default is 0.

  • pwdQualityMinUppercaseChar

The minimum number of upper-case characters (A-Z) required in passwords. Default is 0.

  • pwdSafeModify

Indicates whether the existing password must be sent along with the new password when being changed. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is false.

  • pwdStorageScheme

The method of password encryption. Accepted values are integers from 1-7. The following is the list of accepted encryption methods: 1. Clear 2. MD4 3. PBKDF2AD 4. Salted SHA- 1 5. Salted SHA- 256 6. Salted SHA- 384 7. Salted SHA- 512

  • pwdStrRule

The rule for the password strength, expressed as a regular expression pattern. If there is a value for this property and you want to disable it, set the value to an empty string: “”

REST (ADAP) Example In the following example, a request is made to create a password policy for o=companyprofiles.

https://:8090/adap/util?action=vdsconfig&commandname=add-pwd- policy&basedn=o=companyprofiles&type=subtree&pwdAllowUserChange=true&pwdMaxAg e=5d&pwdExpireWarning=2d12h&pwdMinLength=8&pwdMustChange=true&name=compan yprofilesPwdPolicy 
https://<rli_server_name>:8090/adap/util?action=vdsconfig&commandname=add-pwd-
policy&basedn=o=companyprofiles&type=subtree&pwdAllowUserChange=true&pwdMaxAg
e=5d&pwdExpireWarning=2d12h&pwdMinLength=8&pwdMustChange=true&name=compan
yprofilesPwdPolicy

update-pwd-policy

This command updates an existing password policy.

Usage: update-pwd-policy -name [-basedn ] [-disablePwdContent] [-instance ] [-precedence ] [-pwdAllowUserChange ] [-pwdDictionaryFilePath ] [-pwdEnableAlgorithmUpgrade ] [-pwdEnableLastLogonTime ] [-pwdEnableNotContainNames ] [-pwdExpireWarning ] [-pwdFailureCountInterval ] [-pwdGraceAuthNLimit ] [-pwdIdleLockoutInterval ] [-pwdInHistory ] [-pwdLockoutDuration ] [-pwdLogonTimeSyncInterval ] [-pwdMaxAge ] [-pwdMaxFailure ] [-pwdMinAge ] [-pwdMinLength ] [-pwdMustChange ] [-pwdQualityMinAlteredChar ] [-pwdQualityMinDigitChar ] [-pwdQualityMinLowercaseChar ] [-pwdQualityMinSpecialChar ] [-pwdQualityMinUppercaseChar ] [-pwdSafeModify ] [-pwdStorageScheme ] [pwdStrRule ] [-type ]

Command Arguments:

  • name

[required] The password policy name. Use the value 'default' to update the default password policy.

  • basedn

The base DN for the subject of the password policy.

  • disablePwdContent

If this option is specified, all fields related to the 'Password Content' section will be disabled from the current policy.

  • instance

The name of the RadiantOne instance. If not specified, the default instance named vds_server is used.

  • precedence

The precedence, used to resolve conflicts between password policies. A lower precedence value indicates a higher priority. The highest precedence is 1 and the lowest is 1000. The default value is 1000.

  • pwdAllowUserChange

Indicates whether users can change their own passwords. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is true.

  • pwdDictionaryFilePath

Indicates the path to the dictionary file that RadiantOne should use to verify user passwords don’t contain unallowed strings.

  • pwdEnableAlgorithmUpgrade

If enabled, user accounts that contain a password encryption with a less secure method than the one set for the current password policy are automatically updated to the stronger encryption after a successful bind.

  • pwdEnableLastLogonTime

Indicates if the policy should keep track of the user’s last successful logon time. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is false.

  • pwdEnableNotContainNames

The password must not contain the user's account name or parts of the user's full name.

  • pwdExpireWarning

Used to send a warning, this argument allows a user to set the number of day(s) before the password expires to send a warning. Default is 0 (no warnings).

  • pwdFailureCountInterval

The number of minutes after which the failure count is reset. The default is 0.

  • pwdGraceAuthNLimit

The number of grace login attempt(s) allowed after the password expires. Default is 0.

  • pwdIdleLockoutInterval

The number of day(s) that a user is allowed to be idle before his account is locked. Default value is 0. Note: the -pwdEnableLastLogonTime option must have been set to true for this parameter to be taken into account.

  • pwdInHistory

The maximum number of used passwords to keep in the 'pwdHistory' attribute. Default is 0.

  • pwdLockoutDuration

The number of minutes that an account is locked out for. 0 indicates permanent lockout. The default is 0.

  • pwdLogonTimeSyncInterval

The frequency at which the time of the last successful authentication is recorded.

  • pwdMaxAge

The number of days after which the password expires. Default is 0 (password never expires).

  • pwdMaxFailure

The maximum number of login failures to allow, before lockout occurs. The default is 0.

  • pwdMinAge

The number of day(s) that must elapse between modifications to the password. Default is 0.

  • pwdMinLength

The minimum number of characters that must be used in a password. Default is 0.

  • pwdMustChange

Indicates if users must change their passwords when they first bind to the directory after their password has been reset by an administrator. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is false.

[-pwdQualityMinAlteredChar ]

The minimum number of characters that must be changed when a new password is set.

  • pwdQualityMinDigitChar

The minimum number of numerical characters required in passwords. Default is 0.

  • pwdQualityMinLowercaseChar

The minimum number of lower-case characters (a-z) required in passwords. Default is 0.

  • pwdQualityMinSpecialChar

The minimum number of special characters (non-alphanumeric 7-bit ASCII) required in passwords. Default is 0.

  • pwdQualityMinUppercaseChar

The minimum number of upper-case characters (A-Z) required in passwords. Default is 0.

  • pwdSafeModify

Indicates whether the existing password must be sent along with the new password when being changed. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is false.

  • pwdStorageScheme

The method of password hashing. Accepted values are integers from 1-7. The following is the list of accepted methods: 1. Clear 2. MD4 3. PBKDF2AD 4. Salted SHA- 1 5. Salted SHA- 256 6. Salted SHA- 384 7. Salted SHA- 512

  • pwdStrRule

The rule for the password strength, expressed as a regular expression pattern. If there is a value for this property and you want to disable it, set the value to an empty string: “”

  • type

The type of subject. Accepted values are: group, subtree

REST (ADAP) Example In the following example, a request is made to update a password policy for o=companyprofiles.

https://:8090/adap/util?action=vdsconfig&commandname=update-pwd- policy&basedn=o=companyprofiles&type=subtree&pwdAllowUserChange=true&pwdExpire Warning=5d12h30m&pwdMinLength=9&pwdMustChange=true&name=companyprofilesPwd Policy&pwdGraceAuthNLimit=3&pwdLockoutDuration=15 
https://<rli_server_name>:8090/adap/util?action=vdsconfig&commandname=update-pwd-
policy&basedn=o=companyprofiles&type=subtree&pwdAllowUserChange=true&pwdExpire
Warning=5d12h30m&pwdMinLength=9&pwdMustChange=true&name=companyprofilesPwd
Policy&pwdGraceAuthNLimit=3&pwdLockoutDuration=15

delete-pwd-policy

This command removes an existing password policy.

Usage: delete-pwd-policy -name [-instance ]

Command Arguments:

  • name

[required] The password policy name. Use the value 'default' to update the default password policy.

  • instance

The name of the RadiantOne instance. If not specified, the default instance named vds_server is used.

REST (ADAP) Example In the following example, a request is made to delete a password policy named companyprofilesPwdPolicy.

https://:8090/adap/util?action=vdsconfig&commandname=delete-pwd- policy&name=companyprofilesPwdPolicy 
https://<rli_server_name>:8090/adap/util?action=vdsconfig&commandname=delete-pwd-
policy&name=companyprofilesPwdPolicy

Password policies are managed from the Main Control Panel, Settings tab, Security section,
Password Policies, and can also be managed from command line using the
<RLI_HOME>/bin/vdsconfig utility.

This chapter explains how to add, update, and remove a password policy using the
<RLI_HOME>/bin/vdsconfig utility instead of the GUI mentioned above.
This command prints the current settings for a given password policy.

[required] The password policy name. Use the value 'default' to refer to the default password
policy.

The name of the RadiantOne instance. If not specified, the default instance named vds_server
is used.

REST (ADAP) Example
In the following example, a request is made to display the settings for the default password
policy.
This command adds a new custom password policy.
[required] The base DN for the subject of the password policy.

[required] The password policy name. Use the value 'default' to update the default password
policy.
[required] The type of subject. Accepted values are: group, subtree

The name of the RadiantOne instance. If not specified, the default instance named vds_server
is used.

The precedence, used to resolve conflicts between password policies. A lower precedence
value indicates a higher priority. The highest precedence is 1 and the lowest is 1000. The
default value is 1000.

Indicates whether users can change their own passwords. Accepted values: true, false. Default
value is true.

Indicates the path to the dictionary file that RadiantOne should use to verify user passwords
don’t contain unallowed strings.

If enabled, user accounts that contain a password encryption with a less secure method than
the one set for the current password policy are automatically updated to the stronger encryption
after a successful bind.

Indicates if the policy should keep track of the user’s last successful logon time. Accepted
values: true, false. Default value is false.
The password must not contain the user's account name or parts of the user's full name.

Used to send a warning, this argument allows a user to set the amount of time before the
password expires to send a warning. Default is 0 (no warnings). You can indicate the length of
time in any combination of days, hours and/or minutes using “d” for days (e.g. 1d), “h” for hours
The number of minutes after which the failure count is reset. The default is 0.
The number of grace login attempt(s) allowed after the password expires. Default is 0.

The number of day(s) that a user is allowed to be idle before his account is locked. Default
value is 0. Note: the -pwdEnableLastLogonTime option must have been set to true for this
parameter to be taken into account.
The maximum number of used passwords to keep in the 'pwdHistory' attribute. Default is 0.

The number of minutes that an account is locked out for. 0 indicates permanent lockout. The
default is 0.
The frequency at which the time of the last successful authentication is recorded.

The amount of time after which the password expires. Default is 0 (password never expires).
You can indicate the length of time in any combination of days, hours and/or minutes using “d”
for days (e.g. 1d), “h” for hours (e.g. 4h), and “m” for minutes (e.g. 5m). A value of 1d would
indicate a maximum password age of 1 day.
The maximum number of login failures to allow, before lockout occurs. The default is 0.

The amount of time that must elapse between modifications to the password. Default is 0
(meaning no limit is enforced). You can indicate the length of time in any combination of days,
hours and/or minutes using “d” for days (e.g. 1d), “h” for hours (e.g. 4h), and “m” for minutes
(e.g. 5m).
The minimum number of characters that must be used in a password. Default is 0.

Indicates if users must change their passwords when they first bind to the directory after their
password has been reset by an administrator. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is
false.
The minimum number of characters that must be changed when a new password is set.
The minimum number of numerical characters required in passwords. Default is 0.
The minimum number of lower-case characters (a-z) required in passwords. Default is 0.

The minimum number of special characters (non-alphanumeric 7 - bit ASCII) required in
passwords. Default is 0.
The minimum number of upper-case characters (A-Z) required in passwords. Default is 0.

Indicates whether the existing password must be sent along with the new password when being
changed. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is false.

The method of password encryption. Accepted values are integers from 1-7. The following is the
list of accepted encryption methods:
1. Clear
2. MD4
3. PBKDF2AD
4. Salted SHA- 1
5. Salted SHA- 256
6. Salted SHA- 384
7. Salted SHA- 512

The rule for the password strength, expressed as a regular expression pattern. If there is a
value for this property and you want to disable it, set the value to an empty string: “”

REST (ADAP) Example
In the following example, a request is made to create a password policy for o=companyprofiles.
This command updates an existing password policy.

[required] The password policy name. Use the value 'default' to update the default password
policy.
The base DN for the subject of the password policy.

If this option is specified, all fields related to the 'Password Content' section will be disabled from
the current policy.

The name of the RadiantOne instance. If not specified, the default instance named vds_server
is used.

The precedence, used to resolve conflicts between password policies. A lower precedence
value indicates a higher priority. The highest precedence is 1 and the lowest is 1000. The
default value is 1000.

Indicates whether users can change their own passwords. Accepted values: true, false. Default
value is true.

Indicates the path to the dictionary file that RadiantOne should use to verify user passwords
don’t contain unallowed strings.

If enabled, user accounts that contain a password encryption with a less secure method than
the one set for the current password policy are automatically updated to the stronger encryption
after a successful bind.

Indicates if the policy should keep track of the user’s last successful logon time. Accepted
values: true, false. Default value is false.
The password must not contain the user's account name or parts of the user's full name.

Used to send a warning, this argument allows a user to set the number of day(s) before the
password expires to send a warning. Default is 0 (no warnings).
The number of minutes after which the failure count is reset. The default is 0.
The number of grace login attempt(s) allowed after the password expires. Default is 0.

The number of day(s) that a user is allowed to be idle before his account is locked. Default
value is 0. Note: the -pwdEnableLastLogonTime option must have been set to true for this
parameter to be taken into account.
The maximum number of used passwords to keep in the 'pwdHistory' attribute. Default is 0.

The number of minutes that an account is locked out for. 0 indicates permanent lockout. The
default is 0.
The frequency at which the time of the last successful authentication is recorded.
The number of days after which the password expires. Default is 0 (password never expires).
The maximum number of login failures to allow, before lockout occurs. The default is 0.
The number of day(s) that must elapse between modifications to the password. Default is 0.
The minimum number of characters that must be used in a password. Default is 0.

Indicates if users must change their passwords when they first bind to the directory after their
password has been reset by an administrator. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is
false.
The minimum number of characters that must be changed when a new password is set.
The minimum number of numerical characters required in passwords. Default is 0.
The minimum number of lower-case characters (a-z) required in passwords. Default is 0.

The minimum number of special characters (non-alphanumeric 7-bit ASCII) required in
passwords. Default is 0.
The minimum number of upper-case characters (A-Z) required in passwords. Default is 0.

Indicates whether the existing password must be sent along with the new password when being
changed. Accepted values: true, false. Default value is false.

The method of password hashing. Accepted values are integers from 1-7. The following is the
list of accepted methods:
1. Clear
2. MD4
3. PBKDF2AD
4. Salted SHA- 1
5. Salted SHA- 256
6. Salted SHA- 384
7. Salted SHA- 512

The rule for the password strength, expressed as a regular expression pattern. If there is a
value for this property and you want to disable it, set the value to an empty string: “”
The type of subject. Accepted values are: group, subtree

REST (ADAP) Example
In the following example, a request is made to update a password policy for o=companyprofiles.
This command removes an existing password policy.

[required] The password policy name. Use the value 'default' to update the default password
policy.

The name of the RadiantOne instance. If not specified, the default instance named vds_server
is used.

REST (ADAP) Example
In the following example, a request is made to delete a password policy named
companyprofilesPwdPolicy.
